projectDesc.p: "浪淘沙慢" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the Tune “Waves Scour the Sand, Long Song”
I awaken from dream,
a thread of wind pierces through the window.
I blow out the cold lamp.
How can I bear to be sober?
Listening to the night rain dripping on the empty steps,
sighing that my listlessness,
long makes me a traveler at heaven’s edge.
I have let the fair one down,
so many promises.
How could I have turned
the happy times in the past,
suddenly into worry and regret?
In the gravest sorrow,
I recall again and again,
in the depth of the chamber,
how many times drinks were over and songs ended.
The sweet warm mandarin duck quilt.
Even a temporary separation,
would cost her heart’s strength.
In cloud-and-rain,
there is a thousand and a myriad kinds,
of love and tenderness.
Yet now,
the days are long and the clock drips on and on.
For no reason, I am separated from her.
Who knows when
I could hold the Qin cloud again?
I wish to lower the curtains and sink to the pillows,
whisper to her softly and slowly,
in the nights at this river town,
how I yearned for her as I experienced the coldness.
